731257f-b.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - National Guard and Naval Reserve Units.
731257f-b.text:
Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: Three
views of National Guard and Naval Reserve units marching
hnorthward on Fifth Avenue from Washington Square. These
contingents have just passed W. 10th Street (in views 1
and 2), at the N. W. corner of which appears a portion
of the Church of the Ascension. View 3 is photographed
in the opoosite direction. At the left is the lst Presby-
terian Church occupying the avenue frontare from 11th to
12th Streets. Note the new 8 story Mac Millan and Co.
Building under construction at the N. W. corner of 12th
Street.
1924
MAY BE REPRODICED  Views 1,2,3
731257f-b.folder: 5th Avenue and Washington Square, Manhattan, N.Y.

724018f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
724018f-a.text:
Washington SCuare (Park): The Washington emorial Arch
viewing northward and up Fifth Avenue. Buildings on the left
and right of same, are respectively the Rhinelander and
Sailor's Snug Harbor holdings, fronting on the north side of
Washington SGuare North. Note that at this date the huge apart-
ment house (No 1 Fifth Avenue) has not been erected and that the
old Hotel Brevoort stll stands.
June 1925
MAY BE REPIODUCED  N)eo tt 5ES:

708294f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square
708294f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from and including Washington Square North
and Washington Arch. The Empire State Building, in the back-
grOund, is not cuite completed.
Autumn 1930.
William Frange.
Gift of Bernhard Hoffmann.

724007f-a.text:
19, 18, 17, 16-14 Washington Scuare North at N.W. corner of Fifth
Avenue, the old Rhinelander houses. The large house at the
corner was made by rebuilding old 14, 1S, aad 16. Compare
Brown Brothers' view of this block in 1905.
November 19, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

724020f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
724020f-a.text:
Vashincton Scuare Park:
Washington Arch, Washington Square, seen from the north so as to
show the Judson Memorial Baptist Church (1892) framed in the
archway, and the fountain in the center of the park. The church
stands on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street and Washington Scuare
South (4th Street).
This arch was built around 1890; the wooden one designed by Stanford
White for the Centenary of President Washington's inauguration,
in 1889, was so well liked that it was decided to erect a permanent
arch of stone, which White also designed.
May S, 1233.
P. L. Sperr.

723991f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square East - 5th Avenue
723991f-a.text:
Washington Square Park, the eastern side, seen from the S.E. corner,
with One Fifth Avenue in the background.
May 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
723991f-a.folder: Washington Square East & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

724008f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724008f-b.text:
Washington Square North, at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue,
as viewed from several different angles and showing at that location
the "Rhinelander" an apartment house that was formerly the residence
of the family of that name. View No. 1 is northward from in back
of the Washington Arch while Nos. 2 and 3 are westward from and across
the Avenue.
May 7, 1938
View 2: May 1, 1937
View 31 Aug. 25, 1933
P. L. Sperr,

708293f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square
708293f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north from Washington Square, seen through
Washington Arch. The day on which this exposure was made was
gratifyingly clear. The Empire State Building, the tallest build-
ing in the world, at 34th Street, stands out well, and even
500 Fifth Avenue, at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, can be plainly
discerned.
July 17, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

723992f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 5th Avenue
723992f-b.text:
Whashington Square Park, eastern half, seen across the Squane from
a building near the S.W. corner.
This view is almost straight east on Washington Square South
(4th Street), showing the Judson Memorial Church (1892) and
the clearing made about 1927 on the S.E. corner of Thompson
Street.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but a little further to the north, showing part of
the new One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel (1926), and not
showing Washington Square South.
The apartment building on the N.E. corner of University and
Waverly Places was erected in 1929. Compare both these views
with Ewing Galloway's picture taken about 1924.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
723992f-b.folder: Washington Square South & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

723992f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 5th Avenue
723992f-a.text:
Whashington Square Park, eastern half, seen across the Squane from
a building near the S.W. corner.
This view is almost straight east on Washington Square South
(4th Street), showing the Judson Memorial Church (1892) and
the clearing made about 1927 on the S.E. corner of Thompson
Street.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but a little further to the north, showing part of
the new One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel (1926), and not
showing Washington Square South.
The apartment building on the N.E. corner of University and
Waverly Places was erected in 1929. Compare both these views
with Ewing Galloway's picture taken about 1924.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

723982f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - 5th Avenue
723982f-a.text:
Washirgton Square (Park)1 A set of 3 views of the Washington
Arch, located on the northerly side at Fifth Avenue as viewed from
several different angles. Beyond same apnears the large apartment
house, No. 1 Fifth Avenue which was erected around 1927. The low
structures bordering this side, face on a thoroughfare known as
Washington Square North.
Autumn 1930
Gift of Bernhard Hoffman
William Frange
P. L. Sperr,  View 2Dec. 28, 1927
NO RRPRODUCTIONS.  View 31May 7, 1938.

724012f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue
724012f-b.text:
14-28 Washington Square North, from Fifth Avenue to Macdougal
Street. These are alwost all old resisences of the pre-
Civil War period, except the 7-story Richmoad Hill on the
N.E. corner of Macdougal Street, aa apartmewt house built
about 1900.
1905.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
The same, twewty-three years later. The first three houses,
14-15-16, have been rebuilt as one unit.
October 4, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
